headline: New York Political Map Throws Wrench in Candidates Plans
author: Chad Day and Jimmy Vielkind
sentences:
Rep. Sean Patrick Maloney, a Democrat who represents the 18th Congressional District, said in a tweet Monday that if the proposed map is approved, he would switch to the newly drawn 17th Congressional District, which he said includes his home and many of the Hudson Valley communities I currently represent.?
Republicans are already favored by many election forecasters to retake the House given polls showing voters dissatisfied with high inflation and with President Bidens performance.

David Wasserman of the nonpartisan Cook Political Report said Monday that in his own analysis of Dr. Cervas proposal using 2020 presidential results Democrats likely would hold a 16-5 advantage over Republicans in safe seats with five others that Mr. Wasserman classified as highly competitive.

A court-drawn plan for New Yorks congressional districts would increase the number of competitive seats in the state and erode what had been a significant Democratic advantage under a map struck down earlier this year.

Changes to New Yorks delegation have national implications: Republicans only need to net five seats to take control of the U.S. House, making any advantage in redistricting a potential chance to tip the balance.

It was prepared by a court-appointed special master after the New York State Court of Appeals ruled earlier linesenacted by Democrats who control the state Assembly and Senate and signed by Democratic Gov.
The maps struck down by the court were expected to yield a 22-4 split favoring Democrats in the 26-member delegation that came about due to New York losing a congressional seat after the 2020 Census.
Special master Jonathan Cervas, a fellow at Carnegie Mellon University, wrote that the plan would result in eight competitive seats, compared with three under a proposal from the state legislature.
In addition to New York, maps arent yet final in Kansas and New Hampshire, and a recent Florida state court decision to strike down a GOP-favoring map drafted by Republican Gov.
The proposed map also raised the prospect that candidates would revive, amend or abandon their plans to seek office and potentially pit incumbents against each other.
National Democrats had hoped that pickups in New York would help outweigh Republican gains in states such as Florida where the GOP controls the map-drawing processes.
Mr. Wasserman cautioned that the map could still change as parties in the lawsuit as well as the public will have a chance to weigh in this week on the proposal.
Last week , Judge McAllister ruled against a motion to delay primaries for the state Assembly and statewide offices for the same date.
State and federal judges have already moved New Yorks primary election for U.S. House and state Senate seats to Aug. 23 from June 28.
